I may be missing something here but during handshake initiation you have to deal with 3 possible communication configurations with the new CRC.

 | initiator | peer |
| --------- | --------| 
| old-CRC | new-CRC |
| new-CRC | old-CRC |
| new-CRC | new-CRC |

My reading of the Handshake.java file indicates that the initial handshake has a CRC digest attached.

If the old-CRC is initiating then the new-CRC has to validate against the old-CRC, so it must have the old-CRC code and be ready to used it.
if the new CRC is initiating then it must use the old CRC to communicate with the old-CRC.

So the old-CRC code still has to exist in the codebase and it has to be used for session initiation. 

Is there something in the new code that guarantees that the initiation sequencde uses the old-CRC?

My thought is that we could use another flag in the init header the on initiation being set means (I accept new-CRC) and the a new-CRC supporting client could respond with a message that also has the bit set and uses the new-CRC, so that we can jump into the new protocol faster.
LGTM.  After reading the associated jira I don't see any issues with this code change.

> Besides, I want to know how to make a test ?

Thanks to "Ariel Weisberg" for writing the initial testcase to test the Direct I/O feature. This test [https://pastebin.com/JXJv0tSd](https://pastebin.com/JXJv0tSd) was very useful and showed how fast Direct I/O feature is able to write. Right now, it fails to build so trying to fix it.  Also, I am trying to understand how to do unit testing without affecting existing testcases. Any help will be appreciated.

as @blambov have described in CASSANDRA-18534 , we may support 
`CREATE TABLE ... WITH sstable_format = "bti-fast";`
and 
`CREATE TABLE ... WITH sstable_format = { "type" : "bti-fast", "bloom_filter_fp_chance": 0.001};`
So I just add these methods to see if the options for stable_format is a string or a map, and can correspondingly, we can parse out the corresponding object. 
For other methods , we may get a exception .

I've looked through all the changes, and they look good. I haven't checked the exact numbers for each deprecated annotation yet. I'll do it soon.

I was thinking about adding a new checktyle rule that forces having the "since" element for every `@Deprecated` annotation, and I couldn't find a good solution here. Do you have anything good in mind for this case?

After struggling with this for an hour, I've submitted a ticket for that to the checkstyle project:
https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/issues/13864

Direct I/O testing can be done using existing testcase now. "test/long/org/apache/cassandra/db/commitlog/CommitLogStressTest.java" modified and following table is test result for "test/long/org/apache/cassandra/db/commitlog/PeriodicCommitLogStressTest.java" testcase. It can be changed or improved based on feedback.
![image](https://github.com/apache/cassandra/assets/71302734/f3b53303-d9d7-4784-aa3d-95902ab73e8b)
I could not add new testcase for Direct I/O feature so modified existing one. Build was reporting error so thought to provide this change to allow testing.

Okay so I pulled all the new cep-15-accord code and I think this has been fixed in https://github.com/apache/cassandra/blob/79b3dc07e7f01a315df8db3724db4c1064b8eac9/src/java/org/apache/cassandra/service/accord/AccordKeyspace.java#L361-L363

Jacek had kindly helped with providing a simpler repro than what I was shooting for here. It no longer fails with the most recent cep-15-accord branch. On the other hand if a force 

                updateTimestamps=false;

...in the above, then the repro fails again.

Next steps:

* Rerun the original Elle consistency test to verify
* Seems like we can close C-18798 after confirming ^
* Maybe @jacek-lewandowski you want to submit your unit test as an independent patch

> I could not add new testcase for Direct I/O feature so modified existing one. Build was reporting error so thought to provide this change to allow testing.

for data validation test , I think we can make a test that write using direct io, and using commitlogreader to read the file,then we can just make the data validation test.  also how can we make sure that we are using direct-io ? @blambov Any suggestions?

@frankgh , @Mmuzaf pushed all feedback, can you review again?
@maedhroz we now have retry failure metric.  so we have `total_retries = success + timeout + failure`... we don't have a success metric so thats the only one that must be inferred

@Maxwell-Guo changes are done as per the feedback. Only "mmap" and "direct" I/O modes are allowed in cassandra.yaml and this avoids confusion related to 'standard' mode. Please let me know for any new changes.

One more idea from me is to put sstable disk access mode under sstable options and deprecate the current top-level `disk_access_mode`. That can be the default for now, but we can let it be overwritten in sstable options. In particular, there is an `sstable` of the `SSTableConfig` type. This is used to select the default format and define per-format reader and writer options.

It would be nice if, for a certain format, one could define in its options things like:
`data_read_access_mode`, `data_write_access_mode`, `index_read_access_mode`, `index_write_access_mode`. For the new TrieIndex format, that could even be separated for partition and row index. All of those options are optional and hidden by default. However, for the new TrieIndex format, they could be configured with the optimized values instead of legacy defaults (in particular, their implicit values could be `auto` instead of inheriting the value of deprecated `disk_access_mode` global option).

Something else I forgot: we need an entry in CHANGES.txt about the patch, and the commit messages should use the agreed format (see "Tips" in the contributor guidelines). The UCS description in NEWS.txt does not appear to need any changes.

> I think I have stated most of what I wanted to express. looking forward for your feedback of the code modification.

Thanks @Maxwell-Guo. I will update the PR with changes discussed related to first flush for each commitlog segment.

Summary of changes done to this PR.
1. Moved file initialization from DirectIOSegment constructor to CommitLogSegment.writeLogHeader function. This is required from correctness and performance point of view for each file.
2. Enabled "SimpleCachedBufferPool" pool to re-use the buffers as suggested by "Ariel Weisberg" during initial review of this ticket.  Need to identify Java minimum alignment to use this feature during startup and need to pass this value to same class to allocate the additional bytes to slice the buffer.

Please review.

> I've left some comments and questions. Other than that, just as it was already mentioned, we need a test for the `DirectIOSegment` - it could be a unit test with mocking most of the stuff. We really need to have a coverage of that alignment related stuff. It looks correct as I was reviewing, but additional test is required. I suggest implement it using quick theories so that we catch the edge cases.
> 
> Additionally, it would be great to have some test which can verify different configuration paths.
> 
> We are open to help you with testing and other stuff, feel free to ask.
> 
> I'm going to modify the default configuration to use the direct IO for commit log and run the tests then so that we can be sure that new functionality is in use.
